title: Business Cases for Enterprise Interoperability Collaborative Demand Capacity Planning (CDCP)
segmentation: Planning.
Just in the overview.
The structure.
So we start with a brief Eater presentation.
Then I like to give an overview of the itaa projects.
Then shows that film or go into detail with the business case of collaborative demand, capacity planning, and.
CDCP project.
And afterwards talking about the implementation and the synergies among ITA and coin, and give a summary at the end of the presentation.
So ITA ITA is A was founded in March 2000 as an information technology group for the automotive industry.
It was founded by the VDA.

VDA is the Association of the Automotive Industry and ITA is also very strongly working together and collaborating with the PDA and we are associate members of the of the PDA so very close connection to.
To the auto industry, the aims of ITA is the improvement of the business processes as well as exchange of information between OEM's auto manufacturers and suppliers.
What we do is is consulting.

What we have is members consulting companies as well as IT companies and logistics service providers like VG who are doing all the exports of parts from Mercedes, for example to the US and also the final assembly of cars and things like this.
Members of eaters are about 60 companies like Siemens.
SAP found so far as I mentioned PRG.
And we also participate in international committees and organizations like Odette, so European Automotive Association, AAG from the US site, and OH Ji.
So go Lavita is to establish and verify common projects with the PDA with OEM's was NT suppliers and prepare recommendations for the automotive industry.
So all the projects we start or most of the projects we start, we have a business demand from the industry so this is 1 very important topic.
Of all our projects, and to give you an overview of actual projects and in addition one project we already started, it was, I think 2002.
It was supply chain interoperability, so the starting point for this project was mainly the problem of the suppliers that the OEM's they build their own portals every OEM.
So folks, wagon portal and so on.
Or the other two and the suppliers they have because it's not interoperable with their systems, they have to.
To establish teams working is a relation with with the clients and searching on the portals of these OEM's and it's a lot of effort for them to work this way.
It's not really connected and all the risk is also on the supplier side so.

If one team member gets six, they need to substitute and so on, so this is really not interoperable and so based on this topic, Eater started the project in 2002 on supply chain interoperability and we have some recommendations already in place on this thing to come to the actual projects we work on.
Collaborative demand capacity planning, so this is something which we will go into detail.
In this session I will come to this later on then RFID strategies and standards in the supply chain.
We have already 3 RFID projects in place.
One is out of ID on finished cars, so in RF, auntie on containers and RFID on parts.
And what we do in this project is.
We want to show and and to a up to a proof of concept to define standards and to help it in place in the whole supply chain.
So not only between inside one company or between two partners, but really in the supply chain from OEM tier one Tier 2 and also different companies.
So this is a target of this project and it will.
It will end with a recommendation for the automotive industry.
Then the first project you see here is a innovative collaboration model for.
He has written low-cost cars.
Let's say best cost products.
This is more the target so.
It's very lean.
Lean process is lean solutions lean.
It started the idea started one 1 1/2 year ago when Tata came with the Tata Nano which is a car for 1500 euros and the automotive industry in Europe.
They're saying how is it possible to produce a car for this price?
Even the process costs of the European manufacturers are in this range so.
So it means it needs complete new new ideas.
New Solutions, knew it approaches, and this is the focus of this project.
And finally, we have a collaboration project for Supply Chain in emerging markets.
Is majorly focused on one hand in Eastern Europe, also with Russia, then in Asia with China also and in Latin America, where we have several OEM's and all of the suppliers in place.
And the idea is to to try to find synergies between them to collaborate.
For example, in China Mercy this is in Beijing, for expiring is in Chung Chung in the North.
So.
They discuss things like where to, where to build hops, how to collaborate with all the transportations, and find new ideas of collaboration to reduce costs.
This is their focus.
Now to come to the just one slide to the automotive about the automotive market.
We have major changes also from customer demands.
Customers now look much more to energy efficient cars.
It's on one hand it's question of course, but on the other hand the major question of.
Say social compliancy.
And acceptance and.
For example, if you think about, it's not only between small cars and large cars, so so now merciless has got came out with a new hybrid models S 400.
Hybrid, which is a large car on one hand but on the other hand it's social, compliant and green, and so there is a demand and and client side very interesting and it's good.
Market opportunity for this car too.
And there is individualization's so we have a lot of options and.
More and more people want their individual cars, so it increases the complexity very much in the industry.
Then we have the customer requirements, which leads to a shift from build to stock more and more to build to order and from just in time to just in sequence.
So it's more and more stronger collaboration which is needed to.
Builds this models.
Yes.

Yes, so just in time it's often it's used the time the parts come at, that time when the customer requested, but it could be, for example, that the supplier has got a warehouse and delivering just in time but from its stock, and the idea of just in sequences to avoid stock.
So also the suppliers they asked to produce.
The same sequence as the OEM's so deliver in the right sequence the same sequence as the car is being produced at the OEM side and then to synchronize the delivery with the production of cars.
So really, without any warehouse, it's rusted on the transportation site on the truck where for example seats.
It's a very good example where it is used.

The seats are already produced in the same order sequence as the cars, and then at one point of the production of the OEM the seats are then entered and without any warehouse without control they are.
One to one.
Brought into production and then put in the next car.
Unless you mean it's a requirement from the OEM against the providers then.
Yes to the suppliers to more also synchronize the production and.
Different models on the same production line, as opposed to having.
That's also what, uh, what's more and more common.
So every plant, every production plant of the OEM.
This is put in the position to produce different models.
In the past they had one one Model 1 plant and now they are asking much more flexibility and produce Everything Everywhere for different markets.
Smart manufacturing, yeah smart.
Our cars, yeah.
Reduction.
Yes possible.
It's both, it's an advantage.
Yeah, yeah, it's an advantage for both so.
Finally, it's an advantage for us for the clients, so we buy a car and we have see opportunity to change the car just a few days before we receive it.
So this is this is a major idea to make more business to sell more options.
Is the idea of the OEMs cause a lot of money with the options?
So if you choose large navigation system, entertainment and so on, this is where the real margin is in the car and.
And then for the suppliers is also an advantage 'cause if they have less material, less stock.
Inventory is very expensive, so they have also cost advantage.
So it's for the whole supply chain, it's.
This benefit to produce just in sequence.
Market.
Perhaps for the United States of America.
Yeah it it.
It used to be.
Yeah it used to be for the luxury cars, but now it's more and more.
Also for the other cars.
And it's more if you see the dimensions.
It's depending on the parts so for the high.
Value parts and high volume parts and there it makes more sense if you have small parts like screws it doesn't matter.
So it's yeah, it's more on the value of the parts.
OK, and the certain temporary supply chain networks.
This is something which is more and more common.
So in in the past we had a very strong relation between supplier and OEM which was mainly fixed and not changed.
Now it's really flexible.
The production time of the cars.
It's reduced the life cycle of the cars are reduced, so we have more changing change of partners and if you for example see for expiring and Portia now for example, who is the OEM?
Is a supplier of Portia, so it's everything is moving.
Suppliers can become clients and the way around and the partners are changing so we need interoperability.
To have a fast connection between different partners in the network.
Kim.

Finally, before I head over to its Joseph, I just want to go to show 1 slide about demand capacity, planning, collaborative demand, capacity planning and the situation we had in the past and we have at the moment so.

As you see here we had last year the Market Volume in the automotive industry, but also in many other industries was going down so the information flow, let's say from the clients to the suppliers in the whole chain.
It was quite slow and the suppliers still produced without knowing that the demand of the of the market.
Was reduced so they have a waste through overproduction.
Now we are somewhere in in this area, so everybody is reducing capacity and coming to a situation where the capacity and the demands are matched together.
But what will happen in the future in the future when the demands of the market will increase then we have another problem.
It's we're losing cars, becausw capacities of the suppliers.
Are not matched with increasing demand of the market.

So information is needed and information is needed very fast in the whole supply chain, not only between two partners, we are also losing a lot of time within this supply chain from the OEM to the Tier 1.
Then from the Tier 1 to the Tier 2 to Tier 3, and so on, and the idea of this project is on one hand to deliver information very fast and on the other.
Hand is to deliver the information, have transparency for the supply chain for the total supply chain.
And with this I would like to hand it over to Joseph.
Thank you very much.
